p.s: In his speech given at COP26 World Leaders Summit Opening Ceremony on 1 November 2021 in Glasgow Boris Johnson talks to the whole world population and especially to the world leaders and media to convince them to act against the climate change.
Johnson's speech can be divided in parts.
In the first nine lines he gives an introduction of his speech.
He says welcome to his listeners and starts with an allusion.
Johnson refers to James Bond (l. 2) and after that to his lucrative movies and the doomsday device (l. 3).
He points out the similarity that an imaginary red digital clock ticks down remorselessly to a detonation that will end our lives (ll. 4-5).
He moves on with the antithesis that this is not a movie, it is the reality.
TroughThrough this antithesis Johnson makes clear taht the climate crisis is nothing ot make jokes about.
It is a real issue, which we have to stop.
After that he goes on with his personal experiences and tells the listeners that he was in Copenhagen and Paris, 11 and 6 years ago.
TroughThrough telling something from his life he creates a personal tie to his listeners.
In the following lines Boris Johnson uses a lot of stylistic devices to illustrate that we all have the possibility to change something.
He uses an elipsis to make the fact that we can do something clear (l. 16).
He uses an anaphora and starts three sentences with we can / we have.
This repetition makes his point of view to change something more memorable for the listener and emphazizesemphasizes its importance.
TroughThrough through the inclusive pronouns and language in these lines and the whole speech (cf. ll. 16,22,30,31,39,41) he not just creatscreates a sense of community.
He also makes clear that it is time for all of us to act against the climate change and to take action now.
Especially in his lines Boris Johnson is very hopefullhopeful and troughthrough this he tries to show that everybody can and must take action.
In lines 18 to 21 he goes back in history and appeals to help the world to move to green technology.
In the next paragraph (l. 22-29) Johnson tries to give the audience the message to work together.
He says that we cannot achieve success if just the governments are spending.
So he tries to say that we all have the responsibility.

Through the elipsis and climax in line 30 Boris Johnson encourageencourages the listeners on the one hand to take action and on the other hand he shows that it's possible to change something if we want that.
He indirectly asks this question and makemakes them to think about it.
Through the climax and the last step of it and we must (l. 30) he makes clear that it is the last chance.
After all these appeals, hopeful sentences and problems, Johnson mentioned he goes on with the dangers.
He thinks aobut the future and talks about the children.
This innocent people will come to this world with a totally man-made crisis and this moment it will be totoo late for them to change something.
Johnson shows our responsibility to turn the tide (l. 50).
Because if we won't do that the following generations will judge us and won't forgive us (l. 39ff).
In lines 44 to 46 he appeals again to think about it.
With the repetition of four sentences, that begin with we have (ll. 45f) and this elipsis he shows again that we have the opportunity and the chances.
In the last paragraph (l. 47-51) Johnson concludes his message.
He uses again the elipsis and gives his message that he is hopeful, even if it will be hard (l. 50f).

All in all Johnson uses a lot of stylistic devices to encourage the people to act and through the imagination of a bad future and the judgement from our children he shows how real and important the situation now is.
